abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Sector Reform Capacity
            Building Project's principal goal is to support the
            ongoing implementation of the Government's public
            sector reform strategy, by ensuring that the requisite
            institutional infrastructure is in place and functioning. It
            also seeks to support an important set of cross-cutting
            reforms, in areas ranging from policy coordination, to
            improved financial and human resource practices. It will be
            deemed successful if capacity is strengthened within the
            Prime Minister's office, so that performance
            monitoring, administrative reform, and policy coordination
            functions are established and functioning well by project
            completion. The project components call for: 1) Improving
            policymaking, management of the reform process, and
            strategic communications. Capacity will be strengthened at
            the Cabinet Secretariat, to improve its strategic focus, and
            reduce routine business flows. The component will also
            strengthen capacity within the Prime Ministry to improve
            provision of strategic guidance, and oversight regarding the
            Public Sector Reform Program, and in addition, will
            strengthen communications. 2) Performance management and
            service delivery. This component will ensure the publication
            and monitoring - at the ministerial and institutional levels
            - of performance standards regarding service delivery to
            citizens, through training and capacity building to improve
            its quality, and cost-effectiveness. 3) Institutional
            streamlining. Through the establishment of simplified,
            effective structures, the component will focus on the
            Government's core functions, progressively reviewing
            its mandate, status, organization, functions, and
            administrative efficiency. Increased accountability for
            policy and operations will be supported to improve
            administrative efficiency. 4) Improving human resource and
            financial management practices and procedures. Institutional
            framework and legal arrangements will be established for the
            provision of an effective human resource policy development,
            operational management, and independent oversight. Moreover,
            Budget practices will be improved to reflect policy
            priorities, and encourage effective expenditure management
            through reforms, including strengthened capacity for
            macro-fiscal analysis, institutional reform, restructuring
            of budget preparation and execution.
